route.name: The Fractured Canvas (Verso – Canon Route)
route.subtitle: A fan-made sequel told in linear chapters
route.description: After the collapse of Aline's Canvas, Verso awakens half-paint, half-real in a fractured Lumière. Guided by Canvas Ghosts and the last Writer, he must walk between worlds and decide which truths the city will keep.

pages.text:
When Aline’s Canvas shattered, the painted world dissolved like wet pigment.

The sky bled back into blankness. Streets peeled away. Faces, colors, and entire years ran together and drained into the dark.

But not everything vanished.

Three things remained suspended in the void:

Verso — the soul echo that had anchored the Canvas.
Aline — dragged into the liminal realm she once shaped.
A memory fragment of Maelle — a lingering resonance of Alicia’s ideal self.

Time has no meaning here.
Color is absent.
Reality is faint, like a draft left unfinished.

Verso wakes first.

He comes back to awareness the way a painting dries: slowly, feeling every crack and pull.

For the first time since the fire that killed him, he feels something shocking:

Pain.

Not symbolic pain. Not painted bruises imitating emotion. Real, physical pain.

Aline’s collapse has forced him halfway back into the real world —

but only halfway.

He is tethered between life and unlife, between form and concept.

Something else wakes with him.

In the void around him, a faint scratching sound begins to echo.

Ink on paper.

The remnant of the Writers’ magic.

A force that had been dormant for decades now stirs, sensing the Canvas has fallen.

It whispers, not in sound, but in intention:

"A Painter has broken the world.
A Writer must rewrite it."

Verso tries to open his eyes.

Cold stone presses against his back. Rain needles his skin.

Not Canvas rain — not the carefully tuned droplets that Aline painted to fall harder when a scene needed drama. This rain is indifferent. It falls because clouds are heavy, because air is cold, because the world has decided to continue without asking what mood he is in.

He is back in the real world.

Or a version of it.

He pushes himself upright.

His body does not move as a single thing.

His right side is flesh: chilled, bruised, still carrying the memory of a fire he should not have survived. His left side is pigment: layered oils that shed the rain in beads, glistening without ever becoming wet.

Half skin.
Half pigment.

Half alive.
Half painted.

He is an unstable creation. A glitch between mediums.

The Canvas that held him together is gone. Whatever rules once allowed a painted boy to walk among living people should have gone with it.

And yet… here he is.

Breathing.

Flickering.

He looks around.

Lumière sprawls out ahead — but it’s wrong.

Broad stone bridges stretch across the river, solid and practical instead of ornamented with impossible statues. The cathedral rises in the distance, its façade solemn and bare.

No Monolith.

The streets are empty, but intact. No dripping murals swallowing whole buildings. No floating canvases turning alleys into corridors of someone else’s imagination.

This city has been rebuilt not from Aline’s memory, but from something deeper:

Records.
Maps.
Old stories.

The "true" Lumière.

The one no one has seen for decades.

He staggers to his feet.

His painted heel leaves no footprint. His human heel splashes in a shallow puddle.

"Of course," he mutters. "Of course it couldn’t just be simple."

He lifts his left hand. The painted skin glows faintly even in the grey light, colors shifting between ochre and umber with each pulse of his heart.

He remembers the void.

The moment the Canvas collapsed.

Aline’s face, half-mad with grief and determination.

Maelle’s shout.

The sound the world made when too many stories tried to end at once.

He remembers thinking: *This is it.*

Apparently, it wasn’t.

He tries to move.

The city hums beneath his feet, like something not entirely awake.

In some corners, the light bends at wrong angles. A window briefly shows a view of a sea that no longer exists. A lamppost flickers, its design changing twice before settling.

Lumière isn’t just "real" again.

It is arguing with itself.

One version remembers the war the Painters won.
Another remembers the world the Writers documented.

The compromise in front of him holds both uneasily.

Verso feels that argument inside his own body.

His flesh half remembers hospitals, smoke, and the taste of oxygen masks.
His painted half remembers decks of ships, monoliths, and the scent of fresh oil.

He is a walking disagreement.

A bell tolls somewhere in the distance.

The sound arrives late, like an echo from a memory that had to fight its way through too many rewrites.

Thunder does not follow.

Instead, he hears a quieter sound underneath the rain.

A scratching, almost too soft to catch.

Ink on paper.

He doesn’t know yet that the Writers’ magic has begun to stir again — that the world’s narrative is trying to reassert itself over the chaos of paint.

He only knows this:

If he stays here, sitting on the stones where he woke, the city will rewrite itself around him.

And he might be written out.

Verso stands properly, squaring the shoulders he still half-remembers borrowing from a better version of himself.

He turns toward the bell.

"Fine," he says to no one, to the rain, to the broken skyline. "If the world came back, I’m going to see what it remembers."

He starts walking.

chapters.title: CHAPTER 2 — The Ghosts of Those Who Were Painted

pages.text:
The bell draws him to the cathedral district.

The closer he gets, the more reality wavers.

Streets are mostly stable — cobblestones solid beneath his steps — but occasionally a doorway will flash with impossible color, showing a glimpse of a painting that no longer exists.

He passes a bakery that remembers having a mural of saints on its walls. For a heartbeat, the mural reappears. The next second, it’s just chipped plaster again.

The city is full of almosts.

Verso knows how that feels.

The cathedral stands ahead.

Stripped of the Monolith, it looks smaller than in his memories — human-sized, almost shy.

Stone steps lead up to heavy doors, their surfaces scarred where something once anchored itself. The air around the building tastes of old incense and older arguments.

He takes one step into the square.

"About time," a voice says.

Verso spins.

Sciel stands near a broken column, scythe resting against her shoulder like it never left her hands.

She looks exactly wrong.

The world around her is muted stone and soft rain. She is sharp lines and deliberate color, saturated just a little too much.

The rain doesn’t touch her at all.

"You look like death," she says cheerfully.

He stares. "You’re—"

"Dead? Gone? Confusing?" She shrugs. "Yeah. Pick one. We’re in a city that can’t decide what year it is; I figure I’m allowed to be inconsistent too."

Light starts to gather a few steps away.

At first, he thinks it’s a trick of the wet cobblestones. Then the light pulls itself inward, condensing into a form.

Lune materializes the way a photograph develops: cloak first, then careful hands, then eyes that have always seen too much.

She blinks like someone waking from a very long, very strange dream.

"We’re… thin," she murmurs, checking the edges of her own existence. "But we’re here."

Verso’s throat tightens.

"How?"

Sciel taps her temple with the blunt end of her weapon.

"You happened," she says. "When the Canvas collapsed, most of it went with Aline. But some pieces didn’t belong to her anymore. Some were anchored to you, idiot. Congratulations — your unresolved issues are now people."

Lune nods. "We’re Canvas Ghosts," she says. "Resonant souls. Fragments that refused to fully fade because something in you refused to let go."

Verso wants to laugh or cry or both.

He settles for, "You followed me."

Sciel grins. "Someone had to keep you from moping yourself into nonexistence."

Lune’s gaze softens. "Besides," she says, "if the world is breaking again, someone needs to help you read the cracks."

Verso feels a presence at his back.

He turns.

For just a moment, he sees her.

A girl his age, standing behind his shoulder the way she always did when a scene needed defiance. Short hair, determined stance, eyes full of stubborn, impossible hope.

Maelle.

Only… she isn’t fully there.

Her outline is a shimmer in the rain, a distortion more than a person. Every time he tries to focus on her, the world corrects itself, pushing her image to the side like a smudge.

He reaches out.

His painted fingers brush against air that feels like static and memory.

The shimmer strains toward him, then snaps back, tethered to a distance he can’t cross.

"She can’t reform here," Lune says quietly. "Maelle isn’t just paint. She’s tied to Alicia. To a real body. A real timeline. Until those two reconcile, she exists as a resonance. A possibility."

Sciel nudges his arm. "In less poetic terms," she says, "she’s an echo that hasn’t quite found where to bounce back from yet."

The shimmer by his shoulder flickers.

Verso speaks anyway.

"I’ll find you," he says. "Both of you. I don’t care how many fractures I have to walk through. I’m not leaving you stuck between pages forever."

The echo doesn’t answer, but it steadies for a heartbeat longer, as if listening.

Then the bell tolls again.

Closer this time.

They all turn toward the sound.

Someone else is coming.

He appears from between two half-repaired buildings.

A man in a dark coat walks into the cathedral square as if he owns the space between each step.

The coat is covered in shifting letters.

Lines of ink twist around his arms, coiling and uncoiling with slow intent.

His eyes are black — not empty, but full. Like someone poured fresh ink into them and never let it dry.

He takes in Verso’s mismatched body, Sciel’s saturated outline, Lune’s careful watchfulness.

He nods once, as if a private hypothesis has just been confirmed.

"Good," he says. "The fracture kept the interesting ones."

He stops a few paces away.

"My name," he says, "is Jules."

The rain seems to pause on the syllables.

Verso’s stomach drops.

Jules Dessendre.

He’s heard the name muttered in half-arguments and cut-short stories. Aline’s long-lost brother. The Writer who refused to become a Painter. The family shame. The ghost Aline pretended never existed.

"You’re supposed to be dead," Verso says.

"I was supposed to be a lot of things," Jules replies. "Dead. Erased. Wrong. We all disappoint someone." The ink around his cuffs curls into shapes that almost form words before collapsing again. "Writers don’t die the way Paintress propaganda said we did. We get unwritten, which is much messier."

Sciel squints at him. "He looks like a villain," she says.

"He looks tired," Lune counters.

They’re both right.

Jules looks past them, up at the cathedral.

The building jitters at the edges, its roofline skipping between two designs.

"When your mother lost control," he says, "she didn’t just paint a prison. She tore down the wall that kept our magics from killing each other. Painters reshape form. Writers define meaning. They were never meant to share a playground."

He gestures toward the sky.

Clouds rearrange themselves mid-drift.

"The fall of the Canvas destabilized the boundary between image and narrative. The world is now half Painter logic, half Writer logic. It keeps trying to settle on one version of events… and failing."

He looks back at Verso.

"New Canvases and new Narratives are forming on their own now. Unsupervised. Unstable. Little pockets of reality arguing with themselves about who’s right."

"If we leave them alone," Lune says slowly, "what happens?"

"They spread," Jules replies. "A fracture here in the cathedral square. Another in the old gallery district. More in people." His gaze hardens. "A baker who remembers having three children in one version of his life and none in another. A soldier who died in a painting but lived in the records. The world can’t hold both forever."

Sciel spins her scythe once, metal singing softly. "So what, we’re supposed to fix the entire world?"

"Not we," Jules says. "Him."

He points at Verso.

Verso feels it — the weight of that gesture, like someone just wrote his name onto the first page of a story he never agreed to star in.

"Painters are too invested in how things look," Jules explains. "Writers are too invested in how things are supposed to be. You’re the only thing I’ve ever seen that is both and neither. Half-paint, half-real. The canvas that walked. The boy who died and then refused to stay dead."

Ink creeps a little farther up his neck as he speaks.

"You can step into a fracture and survive both its truths. No one else can."

Verso laughs once.

It doesn’t sound very convincing.

"You want me," he says, "to fix the things my mother broke."

Jules doesn’t flinch at the word.

"I want you to decide what moves forward," he says. "Right now, the world is a stack of drafts. Painter versions. Writer versions. Neither is entirely right. Neither is entirely wrong. If we let them keep piling up, they’ll crush everything beneath them.

If someone like you walks into each fracture and chooses what stays — blends, rewrites, or cuts — the world might survive this."

Sciel snorts. "So he’s your editor."

Lune gives Verso a small, apologetic smile. "He’s everyone’s editor, apparently."

Verso stares at his mismatched hands.

One can smear paint.
The other can bleed.

Both are shaking.

Jules steps closer.

The letters on his coat quiet down, as if giving him the floor.

"So," he says, "here’s the choice, Verso."

He points down one unseen road, out toward the parts of Lumière that are already fraying.

"Do nothing. Let the fractures grow. Watch the world tear itself into smaller and smaller arguments until no one can agree on what they are or how they got here. Eventually, there will be nothing left but noise."

He points toward the cathedral instead.

"Or help me. Walk into the places where reality is cracking and decide what they remember. Help me write a world that can live with what it’s done. Not a perfect one. Just one that holds together."

The rain has slowed to a mist.

The faint scratching of ink in the back of Verso’s mind grows louder.

He thinks of Maelle’s unreachable shimmer.
Of Aline lost somewhere between realities.
Of the people in this city who don’t even know they’re standing on overlapping stories.

He takes a breath he doesn’t strictly need.

"Fine," he says. "Show me the first fracture."

Jules’ shoulders relax, just enough to be noticeable.

"Cathedral district," he says. "Where faith, propaganda, and paint first became indistinguishable. Seems as good a place as any to start."

Verso nods.

Sciel spins her scythe into a ready grip.

Lune adjusts her cloak, steadying herself against the invisible pull of the world’s argument.

Together, they walk toward the broken heart of Lumière.

The world, holding its breath, walks with them.
